Suicide is now the leading cause of death by injury, ahead of car accidents and homicides. Tragically, Australia's rate of suicide is reported to be amongst the highest in the industrialised world.

speech.para: As the member for Mitchell has pointed out in his motion, young males, drug takers and residents of rural areas are particularly prone to take their lives. Over the past few decades suicide rates for males in rural and remote areas have risen and are now higher than suicide rates in metropolitan and regional areas. Suicides using firearms are more frequent in rural areas. Male suicide rates are particularly high for inland remote areas, which have sparse populations, limited access to services, predominantly male populations and high proportions of indigenous communities. There is substantial evidence that harmful drug use is associated with increased risk for suicide. For men and women, the most common method of attempted and completed suicide is drug overdose, with the number of men dying from suicide by drug overdose being greater than the number of women.

Another fact that is extremely alarming is the amount of suicide material available on the Internet. Associate Professor Pierre Baume of the Australian Institute for Suicide Research and Prevention has identified that children on the Internet have access to methods of dying, how to write suicide notes and stories of other Internet readers' suicides.

The increasing amount of research into youth suicide is reflected by a growing amount of recognition by all levels of government of the severity of the problem. Various governments, at both federal and state level, have funded youth suicide research and prevention programs over the past two decades. The National Youth Suicide Strategy, the Here for Life programs and the National Youth Suicide Prevention Strategy, funded with $31 million up to June this year, have all had a common causeâto curb youth suicide. In addition, the government has made changes to the firearms legislation, provided a national drug strategic framework and extended the national mental health strategy, which aims to promote mental health and wellbeing.

I encourage all members of parliament on both sides to commit themselves to supporting measures which will reduce the unacceptably high level of suicide. The National Action Plan for Suicide Prevention consultation draft of December 1998 states that a national action plan for suicide prevention is required for two reasons: firstly, to reduce deaths by suicide and, secondly, to reduce suicidal behaviours, suicidal thinking and the injury and pain caused by suicide to the community. The Howard government realises that reducing youth suicide requires the support and understanding of the entire Australian community. The government also recognises the importance of education and raising awareness of youth suicide prevention issues and providing practical solutions. In 1997 the government formed the National Advisory Council on Youth Suicide Prevention. The Aspects of youth suicide seminar brought to national attention issues involving youth suicide.

It is my view that we need to inform and educate the public, the media, the entertainment industry and help health services about our knowledge in the diagnosis, treatment and prevention of suicide. To the parents of those who have taken their lives, I express my deepest sympathy and regret. As a mother of three, I feel for the mothers, the fathers and the families who have lost a child, a sibling, a relative or a friend to suicide. It is important that suicide prevention is delivered within a coordinated national approach with links to all levels of government and the community. We need to do all we can to reduce this unacceptably high level of suicide. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âEach member of this House has different reasons as to why they have decided to enter parliament. One of the main reasons I decided to become involved in politics was the concern I was feeling over the problems my students were facing. Over the 13 years I spent teaching, each year I saw that my students were facing more and more serious problemsâproblems that young people should never have to contemplate. The current rate of suicide in Australia must be a matter of grave concern for all of us. There are more than 2,400 Australians who die each year as a result of suicide. After motor vehicle accidents, suicide is the highest cause of death for young people in the 15 to 24 age group.

speech.para: There are two main areas that we must concentrate on regarding youth suicide. The first priority must be to ensure that sufficient resources are allocated to help the young people who find themselves in a position where suicide seems to be the only answer to their problems. The second is to address the issues which force our young people into this position. Two factors which influence the risk of youth suicide are unemployment and living in rural areas. For young people at risk, it is vital that there are resources for early intervention to reduce the stresses that are forcing them into the position of believing that suicide is the answer.

It is important that there be education programs available to alert parents and teachers to the early warning signs that a young person may be heading down a self-destructive path. Our youth suicide seminar recently held at Fairbridge in the electorate of Canning highlighted the lack of information and support available to parents in emergency situations.

Another issue of concern is the fact that resources are so stretched with the local groups that it is only possible to concentrate on the young people who are at high risk. This means that the young people who are having problems but are not deemed high risk are not getting all the attention they need. When faced with a family member attempting suicide, the other family members need to be helped to cope with their own feelings as well as be assisted to understand how they can help the young person overcome their problems.

Speaking this week to members of organisations who are involved in counselling those thinking of suicide has highlighted the need for governments to allocate enough resources to deal with the problems. Some areas of Canning have the highest youth suicide rate in Western Australia. The Peel health service is currently trying to get the funding needed to have a PET team in the area.

The major goal, of course, must be to work to create a society where suicide is not seen as a solution, where young people are not forced into a feeling of helplessness and hopelessness about their lives. It is very difficult for young people to tackle their future with a feeling of enthusiasm and confidence if there is little chance of employment. For many, it is through work that a feeling of self-worth and achievement is attained.

In the past 15 years, the number of full-time jobs for young people has halved. The government must allocate the money needed to programs which will lead to real full-time jobs and a sense of belonging to the com munity. Since 1993, in Western Australia the youth suicide rate has been close to 20 per cent. Statistics show that males living in rural areas have a consistently higher rate of suicide than those in urban areas. A number of factors have been highlighted as possible causes, including lack of educational opportunities, high youth unemployment, loneliness and an increased access to means of suicide. In some rural areas, it is difficult to seek medical and psychiatric assistance for early intervention.

Those of us who have experienced either an attempted suicide or the completed suicide of someone close can understand the devastating effect it has on all family members and friends. It must be the priority of all state and federal governments to give the resources needed to the groups which help the young people at risk and to reduce the factors which put them in that position.

talk.start.para: âI commend the member for Mitchell for moving such an important motion in the House. Regrettably, it is a matter which is touching far too many Australian families and leaves many of us mournfully aware of a great sorrow within our communities to which there appears no answer. Our suicide rate is one of the highest in the industrialised world. Its reduction should command the same national focus as does the state of our economy and the state of our national debt.

speech.para: In May 1997, the Standing Committee on Family and Community Affairs, of which I was a member, held a special seminar on this complex and perplexing issue. In its report, Aspects of youth suicide, the committee observed, inter alia, that for some young people acute depression combined with chronic family discord created an overwhelming distress and sense of hopelessness.

The most vexing aspect in trying to find reasons for suicidal tendency and serious depression is that there is no one clearly identifiable cause. It was shown to be a multi-factorial phenomenon. But, from personal experience and from anecdotal evidence, it appears to me that there are often aspects of many suicides, especially amongst the young, that have some circumstances in common. One is a tragic or traumatic life event that occurred in the young person's life in the preceding six weeks of the suicide event; another is significant alcohol consumption at the time of the event, and another is a personal history of marijuana consumption during the time leading up to the event.

It is my contention, and it is the contention of many who have worked in the area of suicide prevention in the wider community, that the consumption of cannabis is one of the most significant contributing factors in the lives of young people who have either attempted suicide, or worse. In its report, Addicted to life, the Salvation Army raised a nexus between the use of this illicit drug and suicide. Important anti-drug organisations like Drugwatch Australia and PRYDE have also identified the consumption of marijuana with our high suicide rate.

Since the 1960s, a significant mythology has developed around marijuana. It is often called a soft drug, a recreational drug or a non-addictive drug, yet nothing could be further from the truth. And the very least that we owe our children is the truth. The truth about marijuana is about personal unhappiness and acute depression. Marijuana can cause mental disorders including acute toxic psychosis, panic attacks, flashbacks, delusions, depersonalisation, hallucinations, paranoia, depression and uncontrollable hostility. It has been shown, according to the Lancet, that marijuana users are six times more likely to develop schizophrenia than non-users. Mental disorders directly attributed to marijuana, as published by the American Psychiatric Association in May 1994, include impaired motor coordination, anxiety, impaired judgment, a sensation of slowed time, social withdrawal and perceptual disturbances, memory loss, disorientation and other cannabis induced psychotic disorders.

This drug contains over 426 different chemicals which directly affect the brainâand cannabis is fat soluble. As our brains are 30 per cent fat, this drug is actually stored in the brain, and tests have shown that the brain is still impaired up to 24 hours after use. Parents of young people on cannabis will know the change in the personality of their youngster from a happy-go-lucky person to one exhibiting depression and hostility.

One important fact that should be noted is the encouraging results that have been documented by the United States drug court experience. Begun in 1989 in Florida as a pilot to reduce drug related crime, the drug courts focus on the person and treat the drug problem as a health and social problem as well as a criminal one. The drug court judge acts as a case manager and, by strict weekly supervision, integrates the support of government departments, community services, rehabilitation and vocational training in assisting people to change their lives to ones which are drug free. Drug testing and treatment are components of the program.

The results have been astounding. Drug courts in the United States have helped make safer communities and have saved considerable amounts of public money. But more important was the sudden reduction in suicide in those jurisdictions where the drug courts had been established. To me this is one important aspect of the success of the United States drug court program which demands closer attention. This is important news for the whole community as it appears, on my reading at least, to be the only program that has been able to report a reduction in suicide anywhere in the world. Therefore, I urge our government to investigate this United States drug court program and investigate it seriously and without delay.

At this point, I stress that the pilot of drug courts in New South Wales is not following the United States drug court example. Regrettably, the New South Wales drug courts will refer candidates to a methadone program which itself has been shown to be a significant cause of addiction. The methadone program is a scandal, and I will be bringing this issue before this honourable House in due course. If we are deadly serious about reducing suicide, we should try to help our young people lead drug-free lives and send them to detox, not put them onto other drugs of addiction. And we have to be deadly serious because suicide is a deadly matter and our kids are still dying.

talk.start.para: âWhilst I applaud the honourable member for Mitchell for raising this issue in the House, I feel it is far too late, as we have done here today, to express our dismay, note with concern and convey our sympathy to the families and friends touched by the tragedy of suicide. We, as politicians, should be ashamed that we have failed the families in our electorates, ashamed that the number of suicide victims continues to grow to a point where we are now rated as close to having the worst suicide rate in the world. We are surely failing, despite the funded programs put in place by both this government and the previous one, to try to stem the increase in the number of our young people committing suicide.

speech.para: Our young people, especially, are crying out plaintively for help to address their needs. Many in this place feel that, because we have allocated moneys to state governments and various well-intentioned agencies in the field, we have done all that is required of us. This is obviously untrue. How many of us, as we work in our electorate offices, daily hear from people, especially the alienated, expressing their utter frustration over their inability to convince the `authorities'âas I call themâof the need to come up with the practical, here and now solutions to their many problems? How often, when we are debriefed over a suicide, do we come to the realisation that what triggered the final act was really a simple, solvable problem to us, as outsiders, but insurmountable to the person who committed suicide?

The basic problem is the breaking down of our family structures and, with it, the cohesive safety nets that are usually in place for all of us in times of stress and turmoil. We adults and us as a society are failing our children and consequently reaping the whirlwind of drug abuse and youth suicide; failing to provide them with a loving and caring home; failing to provide so many of them with a realistic hope of gaining meaningful and rewarding employment; failing to provide affordable housing options, as they set out, often far from home, in their quest to begin post-secondary education or their first job. These failings often place these young people in real jeopardy.

We fail as parents and as citizens to put in place, whether it be in our capital cities, regional centres or in the more remote parts of our country, the basic, local and readily available community resources ready to be accessed when our young people need them. We as a society have been seduced by the economic thought police, whose philosophy is that, unless you can justify the expenditure in the current budget outlays, you should not receive the money.

We are now faced with having to find tens of millions of dollars to try to erase the problem shown nightly on our television setsâthe sight of countless wasted lives slumped in the laneways of so many Australian cities. `Reconciliation' is a word bandied about quite regularly in this place. It is about time we reconciled ourselves as parents with our children, and worked together to rebuild our families, our communities and our country.

talk.start.para: âOrder! The time allotted for this debate has expired. The debate is adjourned and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting.
âI move:

speech.para: That this House calls on the Government to make provision for recurrent funding for student hostels servicing the school access needs of students in remote areas of Australia.

Education is a fundamental human right. For most people in Australia, accessing education is taken for granted. However, for families living in remote areas of this country, accessing education is a right that is labour intensive and costly for the family to obtain. For these isolated families, funding dictates whether or not the children return to school each year. Geographic isolation effectively prevents students in these circumstances accessing the same educational opportunities as metropolitan students in Australian schools. It should be noted that non-government school hostels provide the only access to free government primary and secondary schools for isolated families and that these government schools are the ones most likely to be used by these families in severe and prolonged financial difficulties.

The federal coalition stood up to its election promises concerning the emergency funding for school term hostels in 1998, and the Assistance for Isolated Children scheme increased for 1999. It is the recurrent funding for the hostels that is the only promise not yet delivered. The current situation reveals several existing inequities. If the school completion rates of students from remote, isolated areas are to be improved, severely income affected isolated families will need access to a reasonable minimum number of lower fee, school term hostels in each state. The main reason that most isolated families cannot keep sending their children to school is that they cannot afford the alternatives. Sending their children to more expensive private boarding schools is not an option.

In 1997, the ICPA put a submission to the Commonwealth regarding recurrent payments. Essentially, the ICPA proposed that the Commonwealth provide $1,000 per annum for each isolated student resident in school term hostelsâthis means that the Department of Education, Training and Youth Affairs would pay $1,745,000 in recurrent payments, either directly to the hostels concerned or to the statesâto be matched by an equal state payment of $1,000 per annum per isolated student: a total of $2,000 per isolated student to each registered school hostel. If the maximum isolated student boarding allowance of $4,347 per annum is added to the proposed $2,000 per annum direct payment to the school hostel, plus, on average, $500 to $800 per annum in state government isolated allowances, there is a total cost to government of $7,147 per annum for each isolated child accessing school.

This compares more than favourably with the per student costs of secondary distance education costs of $16,000; education costs allowance for federal public servants of $12,000; primary distance education with radio of $12,000; Abstudy boarding tuition and allowances of $9,000; and, primary distance education without radio of $8,000. If it is acceptable and reasonable to pay a non-government school bus proprietor $68,000 per annum to deliver 20 to 43 isolated children to a town school, it must then be acceptable and reasonable to pay a non-government or government school hostel proprietor a maximum of $72,000 per annum to deliver 20 to 43 or more isolated children to the same school. In the remote town of Hay in my electorate, Claughton House delivers in excess of 27 children to the school gate each day and the government will not subsidise this service for one cent.

Aboriginal school hostels are funded separately. In 1993, the federal government provided an operating grant of $25.8 million to Aboriginal Hostels Limited for the provision of 10 hostels with 360 beds. It is time that the federal and state governments did something appropriate and effective to remove inequities and provide isolated children with the schooling to which they are entitled. The upcoming meeting of the Ministerial Council on Education, Training and Youth Affairs should give all parties an opportunity to provide the adequate and balanced recurrent funding required for school-term hostels to remain open and function effectively in Australia. This will give more than 44 per cent of remote area males and more than 51 per cent of remote area females the opportunity to finish their schooling. I believe that we in government should be aiming to achieve this.

talk.start.para: âOrder! Is the motion seconded?
âI second the motion and reserve my right to speak.

âIt is my pleasure to support this motion today. It is worth noting that the national report on schooling in Australia indicates that remote or isolated students have the lowest year 12 retention ratesâ58 per cent compared with 71 per cent for urban and 64 per cent for rural students. Remote area males have only 51 per cent year 12 completion rates. In the Northern Territory, year 12 completion rates for urban students is an appallingly low 58 per cent. In the bush, it is much worse; it is 35 per cent. The retention rate to year 12 for the Northern Territory in 1997 was 42 per cent, compared with the national figure of 71 per cent. This indicates starkly the necessity to provide a range of service types to enable people who live in remote and rural areas to get their children to an acceptable standard of education.

speech.para: I am fully supportive of hostels, having initiated hostel funding for remote area hostels in the previous Keating government. In the Northern Territory we have four hostels operating. At Alice Springs, St Mary's Family Services has a hostel with a capacity of 30 and last year operated at 100 per cent capacity. In Katherine, Callistermon Hostel, a government run hostel, has a capacity of 40 and last year operated at 75 per cent capacity. There are two Aboriginal hostels in the Northern Territory: Wongkuna-Kari in Tennant Creek, which has 24 places, and Fordimail in Katherine, which has 15 places. We need to appreciate that this is not nearly enough. Not only is it important that we support the motion which has been moved today to provide recurrent funding for student hostels, servicing the need for access of students from remote communities, but we also need to look at the provision of schools.

As a community, I think we ought to be examining the importance of putting in place, in conjunction with state and territory governments, a system of regional high schools with hostels attached to them in regionally important and strategic locations. I can give you four examples in the Northern Territory where, if high schools with hostels attached were present, the participation rates, certainly of young Aboriginal kids, would improve dramatically. These would be in north-east Arnhem Land, south-east Arnhem Land, the Borroloola region and the Tanami region of the Northern Territory. At the momentâand I need to make this very clearâthere are no high schools for any of these kids. We are talking about a very large proportion of the Northern Territory school population who do not have access to high schools. It is not good enough.

We should be saying to this government, as we should be saying to other governments, that, `We want you to provide recurrent funding of the type which is being proposed for people who are currently in hostels'âof that there should be no doubtâ`but we need you to go a step further. Not only do we want you to do this, but we want you to build more hostels in proximity to strategically located high schools. If those high schools are yet to be built, we want you to provide the finances to build them.' Despite the rhetoric we often hear in this place, it is very clear that it will only be when government devotes the financial resources to develop this educational infrastructure that students who live in remote Australia will have an opportunity to get an appropriate level of education.

The implications of this are very important to all of us. Will we see an improvement in the appalling outcomes that I have already outlined and that will flow on to better participation rates in higher education and better opportunities for employment. Currently, because these students do not have access to the most fundamental education provisions, they cannot access the employment training that we fondly talk about in this place. I think this motion is very important and I encourage the House to support it.

talk.start.para: âI rise to bring to the attention of the House the desperate plight of school hostels across my electorate and Australia-wide which are struggling to make ends meet without recurrent federal government funding. In November 1998, faced with the closure of nine rural and remote school hostels across Australia, the federal government made emergency funding for school hostels a priority, allocating $230,000 to hold these hostels over until the government's pre-election pledge on recurrent funding came to fruition. Most of these endangered hostels are still with us today, including Kalgoorlie's Isolated Children's Hostel, but unfortunately this funding came too late for two hostels in Tasmania, which meant some $195,000 was divided among the seven survivors.

speech.para: One of the conditions for this emergency funding was that hostels must stay open through 1999. What we have today is a vital service in limbo. Having cleared their debts with the emergency funding, hostels now need the promised recurrent funding sooner rather than later. Until now, school hostels have been surviving on the smell of an oily rag, raising money from fetes, charity donations, local shires and churches. Clearly, this is not good enough for a country which values education and a fair go for all.

A submission to the Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs by the Isolated Children's Parents Association of Australia earlier this year made it clear that the only way school hostels will continue is if the Commonwealth makes $1,000 per child available to both government and non-government hostels. At present, the Queensland and Northern Territory governments provide recurrent funding of $1,000 per isolated child in hostels. In New South Wales, South Australia, Victoria and Tasmania no such funding arrangements exist. In Western Australia, the state government provides non-government hostels with a token amount and government hostels receive some $1 million per annumâ$300,000 for capital funding and $700,000 for recurrent funding. What the hostels need is for the Commonwealth to come to the party in providing $1,000 for each isolated child in a hostel, which would get all states on board. I call on the federal government to make good on this election pledge.

I am informed by Mr David Houston, Convenor, School Term Hostels, Federal Council of the Isolated Children's Parents Association Australia, that the continuation of school hostels in isolated rural Australia is dependent on the Commonwealth providing $550,000 in recurrent funding, matched by the same amount from the states each year, to maintain some 40 school term hostels across Australia.

This issue is particularly pertinent in my electorate. Of the 1,745 children in hostels across Australia, the overwhelming majority are in Western Australiaâ1,067 in fact. When you are talking about isolated and rural needs, there is no electorate with more isolated and rural needs than the electorate of Kalgoorlie, with hostels in Esperance, Kalgoorlie, Merredin and Geraldton.

Having secured state government recurrent funding, the school hostels in Western Australia have gone ahead in leaps and bounds, with the addition of highly qualified and dedicated staff. The 1,067 students now in school hostels across Western Australia are testimony to this. But still there is scope for so much more. The glaring consideration with the Western Australian experience is that the majority of hostels are taking students at secondary education level. But an increasing trend in the face of rural crisis, with increasing costs and plummeting commodity prices, is that often mothers who teach their children from home are now fully committed in the running of the family property as their husbands, often many miles away, try to earn enough to keep the farm afloat through contract and other employment.

Another disturbing feature sees Western Australia with the second lowest school completion rate of any state. Just 44 per cent of students complete year 12, compared with the national average of 65 per cent. Those who cannot afford boarding schools or who choose to go to government schools will need hostels in regional centres. We have an increasing percentage of non-English speaking migrant parents in the bush who cannot teach distance education.

The rural depression has seen an increasing number of mothers, who usually teach their children, now tied up with running the property. The increasing rationalisation of schools sees the closure of one- or two-teacher schools as commonplace. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âRecently I visited outback and remote areas in New South Wales. During that time I learnt of the difficulties these communities have, and accessing education in these areas is one of those difficulties. That is why governments fund schools and students in these areas at a higher level, and that is why it is essential for this government to support the current funding for student hostels.

speech.para: The one-off funding that was given last year is not good enough. What is required is a long-term commitment to students and their accommodation needs. The government's refusal to provide recurrent funding to hostels, coupled with its decision to cut capital grants in its 1996 budget, shows its lack of commitment to students living in isolated areas. Without suitable hostel accommodation, those students who do not have the option of accessing education locally will be disadvantaged. It will compound the effects of isolation.

Without suitable hostel accommodation, some students will not be able to attend school. The government, along with other governments, has provided support to individual students through the Assistance for Isolated Children Scheme. It is a scheme designed to ensure that all students have access to school education, but it is useless if there is inadequate accommodation, or no accommodation, for the students. I suggest the government rethinks its decision to cut capital funding to student hostels and consider making the one-off grant that was given to hostels last year ongoing.

The decision to cut this program, together with many other decisions of this government, is making disadvantaged studentsâthose students in greatest needâmore disadvantaged. The funding cuts to student hostels will not disadvantage students attending the elite boarding schools. Rather, the decision will work to compound the difficulties experienced by the most socially and economically disadvantaged students. Historically, churches and charity organisations have mainly funded student hostels. In recent times, these hostels have been experiencing difficulties, particularly since the Hostels for Rural Students Capital Grants Program, which operated between 1994 and 1996, was cut.

During 1994 and 1995, the Commonwealth provided $2.6 million to improve the efficiency and effectiveness of the management and operation of hostels for rural students. All eligible non-government rural hostels and the students housed in them benefit directly through better trained staff and better operated hostels. This, along with the establishment of the National Association for Rural Students, went to ensure that those students who needed hostel accommodation to access education would be able to find that accommodation. Unfortunately, this program was not continued after 1996 when this government cut it. The one-off grants given to hostels last year were a welcome injection of funds, as I have already said, but they will not solve the problem.

There are many problems associated with students in isolated areas. Education in isolated areas requires additional time and effort on behalf of students, their families and teachers. The majority of students attending CAP funded schools attend government schools, with Aboriginal students making up almost 15 per cent of those students. When you consider the total number of Aboriginal students attending most schools is two per cent, it is a very high percentage.

Students attending isolated schools have lower attention rates and poorer access to all forms of education. Quite often they rely on distance education to learn. Modern technological innovations have improved things but still it cannot compare with learning within the classroom and interacting with other students. The students in these areas still remain extremely disadvantaged. They have poor attendance and a poor retention rate. They have low literacy levels. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âMay I say at the outset that the body that I would regard as that most capable of enunciating what is needed for rural and remote students would be the Isolated Children's and Parents Association of Australia. While I recognise and welcome the support for this motion that we have had from the other side, some of the talk about calling for capital injection is not, as far as I know, on the agenda for the Isolated Children's and Parents Association of Australia. To my way of thinking, there is not much point spending a lot of capital if we do not have the recurrent funding. The thrust of this motion, I understand, is to encourage the government to look at providing recurrent funding for the existing hostels.

speech.para: Whether we like it or not, and it would be for debate at another time as to what we should do about this situation, times are crucial in rural Australia at the moment. The population is in decline. In smaller areas we have one-teacher schools being closed down. We have the reduction of bus services. What we need is school term hostels for primary and secondary age children where these school buses are no longer provided and we need school term hostels for secondary age children on distance education when they or their parents are not coping.

The problems faced by rural children today are directly proportionate to the problems faced by their parents. Unfortunately, as we know, at the moment commodity prices and drought have hit many of our rural families extremely harshly. The parents are feeling it, and the fact that the parents feel it means there is automatically a flow-on effect to the children. The access they have to education and the amount of money that the parents are able to pay for sending them away to school, be it a boarding school or be it a hostel such as we are speaking about, is no longer there. Not only that, the ability to employ people to help on many of these properties is diminished and we find that not only are a lot of these children unable to access education but they sometimes are being discouraged from accessing further education because of the need to get them to work on these properties.

Access to high quality primary, secondary and tertiary education and training is a basic need of rural people. Geographic isolation means that people in rural areas have less physical access to educational facilities and increased costs in accessing education. Typically, parents living in remote areas are faced with having to pay high school fees for these children or, alternatively, pay for live-in teachers. In addition, the costs involved in having children attend excursions or sporting events can be substantial, loading on again to the cost of education for these unfortunate families. The availability of adequate education facilities can often be a major aspect of the decision made by young families to relocate to or away from a regional centre. As a result, government investment in educational facilities can have a significant impact on the long-term viability of regional centres.

The National Farmers Federation have given us figures, and I understand they have been quoted already, that say that in rural and remote areas 52 per cent of students go on to year 12 and less than 50 per cent of boys go on to year 12. Recently, throughout Australiaâincluding my electorateâthe Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commissioner, Chris Sidoti, travelled around investigating the access that people in rural areas have to different services. He released his report last week and I understand that some of the figures show that, in regional areas in 1989, 25 per cent of students went on to tertiary education. In 1997, that dropped to 16 per cent going on to tertiary education.

The association between the ability to attend school in your formative years is quite clearly linked to your ability to go on to tertiary education. The national trend shows that students are increasingly availing themselves of tertiary education and yet, in rural and remote areas, in a little under 10 years, the percentage has dropped from 25 per cent to 16 per cent attending. We must give kids the opportunity to continue their schooling. The federal government has recognised the cause of the ICPA and increased assistance to the isolated children. They have provided one-off capital funding to two areas in my electorate, majorly funded by the Baptist Church, and that is most welcome. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âEducation in today's competitive market is more important than it has ever been. According to the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Bush Talks publication of 1999:

speech.para: Children in rural and remote Australia are less likely to complete their education than children in regional and urban centres.

Access to education is an issue of critical importance in my electorate. More specifically, access to suitable accommodation for students wishing to complete years 11 and 12 is threatening to severely impact on participation rates of north-east Tasmanian rural students in secondary education.

Years 11 and 12 students living in north-east Tasmania have two public college options if they choose to further their education beyond year 10. They may attend Launceston College or Newstead College to attain their TCE. Both these colleges are Launceston based, and relocating to Launceston is therefore inevitable for most rural north-east Tasmanian families. Years 11 and 12 students in rural Tasmania therefore face additional barriers in furthering their education than other Australian students contend with. Already retention rates in Tasmania are low at 62.1 per cent in 1998, with the national average being around 71.6 per cent.

The National Farmers Federation, in Trends in the delivery of rural health, education and banking services 1997, identifies inadequate access to secondary schools as one of the factors which contribute to the high drop-out rate in years 11 and 12. The effect of inadequate hostel facilities on retention rates is realised when one considers that only around 51 per cent of rural students nationally go on to complete years 11 and 12, and this figure is even lower in Tasmania. We need to encourage rural students to complete years 11 and 12. The government therefore needs to make a commitment to securing recurrent funding to hostels for rural students in Tasmania.

Limited existing hostel accommodation in Tasmania makes it more difficult for students in my electorate to gain enough subjects to complete their TCE. Specifically, rural students in Scottsdale and Winnaleah are able to complete some TCE subjects in their respective regions, but they are unable to complete enough subjects to be awarded their TCE. In my parliamentary colleague's electorate of Lyons, I understand similar issues arise for students from areas like St Helens. Students from St Helens need to travel for almost three hours each way to attend classes in Launceston. Six hours of travel each day is impossible to manage, particularly when coupled with a full TCE workload. The amount of travel required is compounded by the isolation of residents living in Scottsdale and particularly in areas like Derby and Winnaleah.

Failure on the part of the federal government to provide recurrent funding to hostels will also drive rural students out of tertiary education. Without completing years 11 and 12, rural students will be prevented from accessing universities. The existing barriers faced by north-east Tasmanian rural students include the physical distance between place of family residence and the college facility. The physical distance in the Tasmanian context is measured in terms of how long it takes to get to places rather than the distance on the map. There are only limited facilities which provide weekend accommodationâstudents are expected to make alternative arrangements for weekends. This situation is clearly unacceptable, especially for students living on Flinders Island. Years 11 and 12 students on Flinders Island are further disadvantaged because their only option is to fly off the island to complete those years. It is hardly a trip which can be made every weekend, yet weekend live-in options apply to very few hostels.

Hostels provide an essential service in my electorate. Without their continued existence, retention rates of rural years 11 and 12 students will decrease. Without federal funding the writing appears to be on the wall that some of these hostels will cease to operate. As of last year, Launceston College ceased to run Villa apartments and Orana hostels. Launceston College pulled out of providing this invaluable service to students on the basis that it was no longer financially viable to do so. Thankfully, Newstead College currently runs both these hostels on a five-day-a-week basis, obviously excluding weekends. How much longer they will be able to run the hostels is uncertain. With increasing rental costs both of the hostels run by Newstead College face a bleak future without federal recurrent funding.

Escalation in the cost of hostel accommodation will force more rural students to seek out private accommodation options. Such options are more expensive and, more importantly, are frequently less appropriate as they are less structured and do not provide the level of supervision guaranteed by existing hostel operators. This level of security, structure and supervision provides the parents with peace of mind and the student with the right sort of environment to academically succeed. I urge the Howard government to make provision for north-east Tasmanian rural students and to provide recurrent federal funding to ensure student hostels continue to operate in order to provide real and meaningful access to secondary education.

In closing, I remind the government of article 26 of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, which states that everyone has the right to education. This implies that access to education is guaranteed but, quite clearly, rural students are disadvantaged. The government must redress this problem regarding access to education immediately, partly through recurrent federal funding for hostels.

talk.start.para: âOrder! The time allotted for this debate has expired. The debate is therefore adjourned and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting.

debate.para: Question proposed:
That grievances be noted.

talk.start.para: âInternational Women's Day is a good time each year to take stock of where women are going and where we have come from. This year I want to mark International Women's Day by focusing on what is happening to equal pay, because the right of Australian women to equal pay has come under renewed threat, and the ground won in landmark cases since the 1970s is now being eroded.

speech.para: That threat comes from the Howard government and its industrial relations policies, and similar policies being pursued by conservative state premiers. The greatest threat to women achieving equal pay in practice is a deregulated wages system. Australian women have rightly been proud of our historical progress towards achieving equal pay.

Australian women have achieved their progress towards equal pay through our unique conciliation and arbitration system. It was the Industrial Relations Commission that adopted the principle of equal pay for equal work in 1969â30 years ago this year. It was the commission that extended that principle to equal pay for work of equal value in 1972, after Gough Whitlam had the case reopened so that his government could support the union claimâthat is not something we could imagine happening today. As a direct result, the wages gender gap was reduced by about 20 per cent between 1972 and 1977.

As a result of this action and of award restructuring which took place under the Hawke and Keating governments, the gender gap is the narrowest when one compares award rates. Women earn just over 90 per cent of men's award rates. Despite this achievement, this government is bent on destroying the Industrial Relations Commission. Employers argued against equal pay in both of these decisions in the early 1970s. They said they could not afford it; it would destroy the economy and stop the employment of women. After the 1972 decision, the employers and the coalition parties argued strenuously that women's work was not of equal value because it was not dirty and because it was not heavy. They argued that it was not as important; they argued that women would accept being paid less so employers should be allowed to pay them less.

These are the same arguments employers are using across the country now as they try to get workers to sign individual contracts. These are the reasons employers pay women only 48 per cent of men's overaward paymentsâthat is, employers short-change women for the part of their pay over which employers still enjoy complete discretion. There is no doubt that in an unregulated wages system women would do worse for exactly that reason. Employers will discriminate and women will be paid less.

In Western Australia, which has the most deregulated wages system, women workers are receiving the lowest rates in the country relative to men. Western Australian women earn an average of $434 a week before tax, which is a massive $300 a week less than Western Australian men. Within that state, women working in the predominantly female retail trade industry are the lowest paid, earning an average of $310.80 a week. This is nothing short of a scandal.

During the years of the accord, between 1983 and 1986, there was a slow but steady narrowing of the wages gender gap, albeit at a slower rate than during the first push for equal wages. This has occurred especially in industries where women are concentratedâthe retail, health and community services, education, property and business services industries. In those industries, we did see a narrowing of the gender gap between 1983 and 1996. In many cases in those industries now, the gender gap is widening again.

In the hospitality industry between 1983 and 1996 we saw the biggest reduction in the wages gender gap of nine per cent. This has now been reversed and the gap has opened up by four per cent between 1996 and 1999, losing half the ground towards equality that women had won over the previous decade.

The threat to equal wages is real but women, I am pleased to say, are continuing to fight for it and are being successful. We have just had, in the last year, the first arbitrated case for an equal remuneration order taken to the Industrial Relations Commission. It concerned the electrical company HPM, and there has been a major victory for women there.

The equal remuneration provisions enable workers, unions and the Sex Discrimination Commissioner to seek orders for equal remuneration, including over-award paymentsâand that has been in our legislation since 1994. They represent the next step in the commission's historic role of addressing equal pay in this country because they allow the commission to make orders about over-award payments. Peter Reith, the former Minister for Industrial Relations, tried to take them out of our industrial relations system, but was forced by a campaign by women's groups and the unions to put them back into the Workplace Relations Act.

The HPM case was settled after three years of proceedings. The opposition to the case by the company was intense. It ranged from delaying tacticsâto see, of course, whether the provisions were removed by the governmentâto obstruction of competency standards processes which ultimately showed that the women were more skilled than the men, to the sacking of the men and rehiring of them in higher classifications. The claim involved the union seeking, for 300 female process workers, the same rate of pay that was paid to some dozen male general hands and, for 20 female packers, the same rate that was paid to male storemen.

The case was a classic illustration of why women do not yet receive equal pay in practice. The women and men were segregated into jobs based on their sex. The process work and packer jobs were women's jobs; the general hands' jobs were men's. There was a strong view held by the company that the men's general labouring duties were more physically demanding than the women's. They were required to move components and finished goods, such as electrical plugs and power points, around the factory. The women performed highly intricate assembly involving tiny components. They suffered significant overuse type injuries involving shoulders, arms and hands. Under the competency standards, the women were assessed as having to exercise a higher level of skill than most of the men; in some cases markedly so. But the company argued that the men's work was more important.

With respect to the work of the packers compared to that of the male storemen, the work was basically interchangeable, but the men were required to check the women's workâanother example of a straight gender discriminatory aspect of work organisation that is all too common. The men had access to a three-tiered performance based wages structure that was not open to the women. The men also had a range of discretionary over-award payments which appeared to be based on service, although the company denied it. Long-serving women, by and large, did not receive any over-award payments.

The case was finally settled in December last year, after protracted industrial relations and intensive negotiations. In the course of the 2Â½ year agreement that has been signed, the women will receive the actual amount sought by the union. For the process workers this is $463, which is the amount that was paid to the highest paid general hand in the factory. Most importantly, however, the discriminatory wages system that applied has been abolished. All workers on the same classification level will get the same rate of pay. Some of the highest skilled women have been reclassified upwards. It has been a great victory for the women at HPM, and I certainly extend to them my hearty congratulations.

I want to finish with the other major threat to the living standards of Australian women, and that of course is the government's tax package. The benefits of the government's tax package are going to flow disproportionately to men rather than to women. Men, of course, earn higher wages and women are less likely to work full-time. Compare this: a single man earning $80,000 gets a $68 a week tax cut. A sole parent with two children earning $10,000 a week gets $17 a week. In other words, she gets four times less and has to spend it on three people.

Labor's tax credit, by contrast, was designed to provide much needed tax relief to a majority of workers, particularly low income workers, many of whom were women. The whole purpose of the tax credit was to encourage women to take up part-time work and, in doing so, we were going to make sure that those women and their families were better off. It cut the tax bill of a family earning $30,000 by half. It is a much more generous tax proposal than the one the government has before the parliament.

The government is making it harder for sole parents to go back to work. It is not going to be worth their while because of the tax they have to pay, the social security they lose and, of course, the child-care fees that have been increasedâand all of this on top of a GST. Let me say that women will continue to pursue equal pay as they have done for many years in this country. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âI just note for the record that the CEO of Australia's largest corporation and business is a woman, and it is good to see.

speech.para: Last week my office was contacted by the parents of some young primary school aged children. These parents were outraged at the lyrical contents of a promotional giveaway cassette being distributed by a local radio station. The cassettes that were being handed out, along with other free giveaway products, to the young students of Railway Estate Primary School in Townsville, contain shocking, explicit material in the lyrics on the first track. According to the radio station, staff were caught out by the lack of a sticker that the producers of the tape should have applied to the cassette case, warning of explicit language.

As a parent, and as a parliamentarian, I am concerned that explicit material such as this could have so easily been put into the hands of innocent eight-year-old children. Robyn Riley, a constituent in the Herbert electorate, has raised such concerns very directly and forcefully. Mrs Riley has taken the time to examine the lyrics of many compact discs in the heavy metal section of your typical local music store.

Among her findings were bands that `glorified the atrocities of Auschwitz, and talked of ripping and gouging flesh, drinking blood, killing cops and raping women. `Would you be comfortable if your son or daughter were to sing along to music like this?' Mrs Riley asks. It is a good question, and for me the answer is a flat no. Robyn Riley compares the effectiveness of the 18+ warning stickers that appear on CDs containing explicit language as being `no different from prescribing panadol for bowel cancer, resulting in no effect as the rot sets in.'

Following the recent incident in Townsville where graphic material was put into the hands of very young children, I believe it is time to take a hard look at the effectiveness of consumer protection measures as they relate to the music industry. It is incumbent on all of us to bear in mind that the character of today's young people determines the condition of tomorrow's society. Clearly, parents such as Robyn Riley feel they are losingâand in many cases have long since lostâthe ability to protect their children from some of the less attractive aspects of modern life.

How does a tape containing explicit lyrics get into the hands of young children? How did the industry standards fail to be applied in this instance? Are the 18+ warning stickers that only `recommend' that certain CDs or albums are not suitable for persons under the age of 18 years adequate protection? And what steps can be taken to ensure that this never happens again? These are the questions to which I want answers by the Australian Record Industry Association, the censorship board and by this parliament.

As a Liberal I am mindful of the question of censorship and of infringing upon an individual's liberties. But as a parent I am also mindful of the impact of explicit material on our young people. This is a pressing issue that needs to be thoroughly examined in the public domain.

The other issue that I want to canvass today is that of the Child Support Agency and family law systems. There are some days when I wake up and feel as though I am a member of an endangered species, that species being a happily married parent who has, in a close loving partnership with my wife, successfully managed to raise two children who are now off forging their own lives.

An article I read recently set out in stark terms why sometimes I feel like something of an endangered species. The article appeared in the Sydney Morning Herald last November and ran through a series of statistics with regard to the situation of fathers who have separated from their partners. One in three fathers face the prospect of their marriage failing before their children are reared. One in 10 of those fathers face the risk that they will not have any contact with their children before they become adults.

The article went on to say that each day 77 fathers in Australia separate from their child's mother, of which 71 of these fathers will not be living with their children five years later. Every day of the year an additional 23 Australian fathers lose contact with their children, leaving another 36 fatherless children. There are almost 558,000 separated fathers who are denied as much contact with their children as there should beâthe flip side being that there are 892,000 children who are denied the degree of care their father is willing to offer. In fact, the article states:
There are 291,000 children who see their father less than once a year.
These figures are shocking, even when you do allow for a margin of error.

I was curious to find out what the situation was like in Townsville, so I did a check to see how many Child Support Agency clients reside within my electorate of Herbert. As of December 1998 there was a total of 9,577 CSA clients residing within the Townsville area. No wonder I sometimes feel as though I am part of an endangered species.

There is a saying that has become something of a theme for those people, and particularly fathers, battling for reform within the CSA and family law system. That saying is: `I divorced my partner, not my children.' Indeed, that is one of the conclusions reached in the Sydney Morning Herald article. Its author, Peter Vogel, said:
The court must reinforce the idea that when parents divorce, they divorce each other, not their children.

And I agree with that sentiment. I am enough of a realist to know that there are instances when it would not be in a child's best interest to have contact with one or the other parent for reasons of safety or the potential for violence and abuse. But, in the main, I firmly believe that it is in the child's best interest to have consistent and meaningful contact with both parents, particularly in their formative years, even if a marriage does break down.

While I have used the term `fathers', in a smaller number of cases you could interchange the word `mothers' and have the same result and draw the same conclusion. This is not a statement which is biased towards one sex or the other; it is just a statement of the fact of what is happening in Australia today.

There is much debate about the `stolen generation', which is a black mark on our national psyche that we are still trying to come to grips with today. But there are also parents who feel as though their children are being stolen from them every day as a result of the Family Court system. I cannot help but wonder whether in years to come we will look back with the same regret on the Family Court system and wonder how we managed to create a system that did not better facilitate joint custody arrangements.

The former Labor government, to their credit, did start to reform the child support and Family Law Court system. The Howard coalition government has carried on that process. One of the achievements of the Howard government has been the emphasis we have put on family and relationship support. The Relate education program that aims to help couples sustain and improve the quality of their relationship is another great example of that. In terms of reform within the CSA, and in particular the family law system, I cannot help but feel that we have only begun to scratch the surface.

talk.start.para: âI want to use this grievance debate to raise my concern about the unprecedented level of illegal drug activity in the community. In the last four weeks in just one shopping centre in my suburban electorate there have been several overdosesâone necessitated 15 minutes of mouth-to-mouth resuscitation before ambulance staff arrived. Police tell me that high-grade heroin has never been cheaper nor as freely available. But if I thought the overdoses in Perth's northern suburbs indicated that the problem of illicit drug use was at critical levels, I was even more appalled to see just how bad it has now become Australia wide. The Canberra Times reported late last week of an `unprecedented wave of drug-overdose emergencies', where one person died and 18 more overdosed, all before 5 p.m. and all in daylight hours, in this nation's capital.

speech.para: I also learnt last week of an inland country town, with a population of some 5,000, where 31 people are on a methadone program, with 80 people waiting to come on. The particular agency I was talking to told me that they are now treating kids as young as 14 years of age for various forms of substance abuse and drug addiction, including exposure to heroin. The age of drug users is coming down, and the drug problem in Australia is set to worsen. This is despite the Prime Minister coming into this House, answering dorothy dixers, telling us how effective his Tough on Drugs program is.

In a story by Alan Kohler in the Financial Review late last week, the United Nations International Narcotics Control Board predicted a further 25 per cent rise in the supply of opiates around the world. They reported that the INCB's forecast is for the increase in production to result in a 140 per cent rise in the excess supply of opiatesâfrom 50 tonnes of morphine equivalent last year to 120 tonnes this year. In the article, Alan Kohler went on to say that the price of heroin in New South Wales has dropped in a year from $400 a gram to $280 a gram. On a per cap basis, he reported, it has dropped by anything up to half, and is now as low as $25 per serve.

That drop in price is not confined to New South Wales. From my own anecdotal evidence, I am told that starter kits, aimed at kids in both primary and secondary schools, now sell for as low as $5 in various parts of Australia. In short, it is clearly apparent that an insidious blanket of heroin-woven death and misery is being wrapped around young Australians. Illicit drug use is a divisive and emotionally charged issue. It divides families, it divides communities and, from the arguing and bickering that is going on around Australia, it certainly divides governments from within and without. The result is that, in a leadership vacuum, we see various states and the Commonwealth fighting over which response is most philosophically correct.

It is such a divisive issue that last week in WA, Mr Paul Clune, Secretary of the metropolitan branch of the Western Australian National Party, savaged Rhonda Parker, state Minister Responsible for the Drug Abuse Strategy. He said of her in the West Australian on March 4:
To say "trials do not lead to addicts kicking the habit. . . " is either a lie or a false belief.

The minister in Western Australia is under fire from many fronts, but particularly for withdrawing an invitation to Tony Trimmingham, a person requested by non-government drug action groups, to address a drug summit in Perth. The invitation was withdrawn when, surprisingly, it became evident that he did not share the minister's view on heroin trials. So much for free speech, and so much for the Western Australian government's self-acclaimed drug strategy of `together against drugs'.

I agree with Duncan Kerr, Labor's spokesman on drug strategy, when he said, I think it was last week, `We must leave no stone unturned in the fight against drugs.' For that reason, I am rather appalled that the Prime Minister should choose to ensconce himself within his inherently weak and personal philosophical bunker, consulting only those who support his views on the drug issue. It is no wonder that his `all the way with LBJ' approach to New York police methods led Duncan Campbell of the Australian to recently write that the Prime Minister's heroin strategy could prove to be `Howard's Vietnam', with a subheading comment which said:
While the Prime Minister wages war on drugs, the body count climbs.
He went on to say:

The Prime Minister is encouraged to make war on the smuggling and sale of heroin. He risks falling victim to the old anti-Vietcong syndrome in which the longer you fight and the stronger the opposition, the more loudly you are compelled to claim victory.

And we have certainly heard plenty of that from this government. It is a war on drugs, but the young Australians of today will not be sent to Gallipoli, New Guinea or Vietnam to confront the enemy. Their war is right here in the suburbs and the country towns of Australia. It is in the schools, the local streets, the shopping centres and the places of entertainment that young people frequent in their own communities. Their enemy is the non-using pusherâthe up-front, sleazy young punk or the hidden, respectable business person who is growing rich on the profits of drug sales. Illegal drug trafficking is a billion dollar business in Australia against which governments are merely throwing loose change, with strategically flawed and fragmented policies which, as long as they are divided, are doomed to fail. Not only do we need an effective national strategy; in my view, we need a full-blown, federal and state funded and supported royal commission into the drug problem in Australia. A royal commission that should range from the means of attacking the drugs at their source, in the countries in which they are grown, to how they are imported, to their distribution and sale in Australia by whom and how.

The royal commission must also focus on the problems of addiction and the social and medical strategies necessary to detoxify, treat and rehabilitate the victims of drugsâthe addicts themselves. It should also provide access for the many dedicated, volunteer-driven, non-government organisations to have a sayâorganisations which achieve much in the fight against drugs and provide great support to the families of those addicted, particularly parents, who are so often left high and dry when they endeavour to come to terms with their child's drug habits.

In my view, we must take the drug problem out of the political arena. The only way we can do that is by establishing a royal commission. A royal commission would give those in the medical profession, other caregivers, teachers and law enforcement officers an opportunity to have a say in a royal commission and to contribute to a national strategy to combat drug abuse.

It is fine for the Prime Minister to call for a bipartisan approach to the drugs crisis, but if there is no option at the same time to develop bipartisan policies what is the point? A royal commission could review antidrug legislation around Australia, just as it could evaluate drug enforcement, its level of resourcing and its effectiveness.

I know there are many people who will scoff at the suggestion of a royal commission as being unnecessary and a waste of money. But how else can we confront the issue of drugs in Australia in a non-political way? How else can we enlist the support of the greater majority of Australians in this fight? How else can we link hands and stand shoulder to shoulder against this invasion of drugs, which has the potential to decimate young Australians, causing continued increases in crimes of stealing and violence and greater insecurity for innocent people, particularly the aged, who are much more vulnerable as targets of crime by those seeking money to support a habit?

It needs to be said that the drug problem is not just a capital city problem; it is an issue in the bush, and the bush represents a growing market for the pushers. It is not just a problem for governments federal, state or local; it is a problem for the whole of Australia. It is a problem which demands a national strategy. A royal commission would give us a chance of achieving that strategy. Indeed, nothing else that I can see coming out of Canberra does.

This is not a war which should be waged by individual states; it is a war that should be waged by a nation. Unlike America, Australia must confront the drug issue as a whole of nation issue. We must do it now because if we do not, not only are we letting down this generation of young people but also the next.

subdebateinfo.title: Employment: Closure of Ashanti Copper Mine

talk.start.para: âI rise to speak on an issue that is well known in this place: the lack of guarantee of entitlements to workers by the financial difficulties that some multinational companies find themselves in. I refer especially in my electorate to the town of Cobar. I also recognise the role that the member for Prospect has played in drawing this to the attention of the House and the Australian people. I would like to add my thoughts to hers.

speech.para: The threat posed to small regional centres by the fluctuating fortunes of large companies was well illustrated by the experience we had in Cobar in western New South Wales in early 1998. After the collapse of the Ashanti copper mine in January, 250 jobs were lost and, for almost a year, negotiations continued in the hope of securing for the miners the money that they were owed.

In supporting steps to guarantee the payment of long service and holiday pay in the event of a similar situation, the far-reaching effects of this crisis on the town of Cobar should be highlighted. While the 85 cents in the dollar payment was eventually received by the affected minersâand I should point out that the businesses in the Cobar area received substantially less than thisâit should be noted that the hardworking Australians still lost 15 per cent of the money to which they were rightfully entitled. It is all very well for us to congratulate ourselves and to pat ourselves on the back with regard to the victory that we had in securing the 85 cents in the dollar payment from Ashanti, but I would like to draw attention to the fact that these people were still entitled to a further 15 cents in the dollar.

The broader crisis sparked by the mine closure really illustrates the vulnerability of regional communities to any lack of income. This situation is crystallised in an area like Cobar, particularly when you compare what happened there with what might arise if the same thing happened in Parramatta or some other place in Sydney. Because the economy of the town of Cobar relies so heavily on this mine and some others, they have been far more vulnerable to the impact that this closure has had. Most shocking, from my point of view, was the need for food parcels to be distributed to some of the unemployed miners and their families. They were unable to receive welfare benefits because of the assets they owned. I might point out that Centrelink moved heaven and earth to provide a service to those people in Cobar, and they should be recognised for that.

Many of these people found themselves in an uncommon situation. It was the entrepreneurial minersâthe ones who had actually put aside money and then borrowed money for a house, for exampleâwho were in more trouble than the ones who just spent their entire income. These people may have borrowed, for ease of maths let us say, $100,000 to pay for their homes. When the crisis hit, 100 families were forced to leave the town and real estate prices tumbled. So many of these people could not sell their houses, recoup their money and then live in rental accommodation. If they did sell their houses they would still owe half of what they owed previously and they would also have to pay rent.

These people were the ones most harshly affected. These were the people who were demeaned by having to rely on food parcels. A plunge in both price and level of demand in this housing market was one of the key factors in causing heartache in many of these households. This spin-off impact was only one of several devastating developments that followed the mine's closure. Economic stagnation and, as I said, the ensuing exodus of population from this isolated western centre caused even greater social and economic hardship, according to a study by the Charles Sturt University, funded by the Orana Regional Development Board.

I would like to take this opportunity to thank the federal government for their continued funding of the Orana Regional Development Board and its research into the possibility of providing more employment for towns and people in my area. The federal government has funded a fairly large study specifically for Cobar, which has unearthed the possibility of several new initiatives that may provide some relief for the town.

We were lucky to some degree in this case that we actually received this payment from Ashanti because of the presence of a letter, I understand, which showed that the company recognised that they were trading insolvently. It was through this channel that the Australian Securities Commission was able to pursue the parent company in the courts. If this letter had not been in existence, we might have been in a different situation. Even though the result was not ideal, we might have had a far worse result.

Bearing this in mind, I stand here to request that we look at different ways of providing security of income for workers in Australia. I recognise the government has done a lot in moving through the right chain of events to prevent this from happening again and I commend that recommendation to the labour ministers council. I would also like to say we should not let this thing stagnate. We must act on recommendations that might be forthcoming from this council.

There is an argument that, if we impose too harsh a restriction on the setting up of business and the funding of entitlements, that may discourage other businesses from actually getting off the ground. To some degree I dispute this. While I come from a regional centre and while I believe we must be very careful that we do not discourage any activity which is going to result in more jobs for our people, there must be a recognition that the rights of our workers must be protected.

Perhaps in a similar case, if a business is being sold and employees have been employed for five years or longer, provision must be made in the sale agreement for long service leave to be put aside. Perhaps that is one area that we could look atâthat any money that is owed to employees for long service must be put aside and fully funded for those employed for five years onwards. That is perhaps one area of consideration. The impact of a situation like this on Cobar, as distinct from anywhere else, really only serves to clarify the need for us to go forth and find a resolution to this problem.

Before I close I must recognise the role that a few peopleâcertainly my predecessor, Michael Cobb, though much malignedâhave played in this. It turns out that he was right all along with the avenue that he was pursuing. I mention Steve Roach, even though I understand that those on the other side do not recognise that he represents a union. I am not sure of the complete ins and outs of that, but Steve Roach played an important role in keeping the town together and supporting the miners. He did an awful lot to reach a position where this was resolved and he is held in quite high regard by everybody I speak to in Cobar. I also mention the council and the mayor, who played an important role in facilitating this outcome. Sure, all of the people that I have mentioned did not get on all the time and did not agree with every process in the situation, but in the end the important thing was that a reasonably satisfactory result was obtained. However, as I said earlier, I believe that this was to some degree a case of good luck rather than good management.

talk.start.para: âMy grievance today is the disincentive to work, faced by many working families in my electorate of Canberra, as a result of high effective rates of taxation. In the past 20 years we have witnessed a period of significant change in the delivery of social services in Australia. Australia has adopted a `selective' welfare system, a system of selective `social assistance' rather than one of universal `social insurance'. A key aspect of this change has been the extensive use of means testing to determine eligibility for social security payments. The introduction of means testing has resulted in a much more complex tax transfer system. It has also led to a proliferation of social security payments.

speech.para: Many of these new payments are a response to emerging needs in our society. For example, partner and parenting allowances have been introduced, reflecting the changing role of women in our society. In addition to the more complex array of outlays, complexities have also developed on the revenue side. One key problem created by this mesh of overlapping means tests is the production of very high marginal tax rates, particularly where the income support means tests overlap with the income tax system.

In the past few years concerns have been expressed about the impact of these high effective marginal tax rates on low and middle income families. A recent study by Gillian Beer and Ann Harding of the University of Canberra's National Centre for Social and Economic Modelling, or NATSEM, has found that those facing high effective marginal tax rates, or EMTRs, are most likely to have children. According to NATSEM, 75 per cent of those facing very high marginal tax rates have children. NATSEM has found that nearly a quarter of sole parents and one in 10 couples with children face EMTRs well in excess of 60 per cent. The main cause of these high EMTRs for sole parents is the sole parent pension income test.

However, despite common public perceptions, high income families are not facing the high rates. Instead, those in the lower half of the income distribution face them. NATSEM has found that just over a quarter of people in the fourth income decileâthat is, people with an average gross income of $26,000 per annumâface EMTRs of more than 50 per cent. In sharp contrast, no-one in the top 40 per cent of income distribution face EMTRs of over 50 per cent.

The available evidence suggests that women face the highest EMTRs, and hence the biggest disincentives to work, particularly when their husbands are on low to moderate incomes. For example, a family where the father earns $25,000 and the mother starts to earn income will lose 84c for every extra dollar the mother earns.
