This is because, for each dollar that she gets from her job, the family loses 50c of the family payment and pays 34c of income tax. The working mother is left with 16c as a reward for working, and the costs of child care will very quickly swallow this up. She would legitimately ask, `Why bother working?' Yet families in these circumstances desperately need that extra money.

Labor's earned income tax credit proposalârecently supported by others including the Business Council of Australiaâhas been developed to address this problem. The tax credit proposal would enable working mothers to keep more of every dollar they earn and would actually reward women for doing extra hours of work where currently they are penalised. The tax credit proposal will substantially reduce the effective marginal tax rates faced by many low and middle income working families and provide real help for parents who are returning to the work force.

There can be no doubt that the tax credit is a much needed reform of the Australian tax and transfer system. Without it, the incentives for families to increase their hours of work or to return to the work force if they are unemployed will become weaker over time, with serious consequences for unemployment, labour force participation and living standards. The problem is particularly prevalent for sole parents. Kathleen Swinbourne from the sole parents union puts it bluntly:
It's simple: there's no financial incentive for single mothers to go out to work.

Data from the Australian Bureau of Statistics show that the national labour force participation rate of sole parents has fallen from 50.5 per cent when the Howard government was elected to 49 per cent in June of last year. The fall has driven a broader decline in the proportion of mothers with children under 15 who are participating in the work forceâa fall from 59.1 per cent to 58.6 per cent over the same period. The evidence is that more than two-thirds of the nation's discouraged workers are women. This demonstrates the obvious fact that women have not fared well under the coalition's industrial relations regime. Wages for part-time workers have fallen and because of the concentration of women in both full-time and part-time jobs, the gap between men's and women's earnings is widening. Women on average earn $466.40 a week while men on average earn $708.80 a week. That is a pretty stark difference. The National Institute of Labour Studies has found that:

. . . the main factor underlying a deterioration in earnings outcomes for women relative to men in recent years is their greater concentration in part-time work. Furthermore, the evidence suggests that part-time workers fare less well because enterprise bargaining is far less likely to occur in such firms.

The Australian Labor Party is committed to eliminating the gap between what men and women earn. We believe in equal pay for equal work. We believe that wage bargaining should be fair and that part-time workers should not fall behind full-time workers.

It is a matter of considerable concern to those on this side of the House that women remain concentrated in lower paid and lower skilled jobs. Women are more likely to work part time, more likely to experience periods out of the labour force and more likely to require support to balance work and family responsibilities throughout their lives.

The introduction of an earned income tax credit for working families is an important part of an overall strategy to reduce poverty, ease poverty traps and simplify the confusing array of family payments and tax rebates. The support that the tax credits proposal has received from senior economists and the Business Council of Australia is welcomed and demonstrates an emerging consensus on the issue. In this context, it is disappointing that the government has chosen to isolate itself by rejecting the tax credits approach.

The government's solution to lower wage rates and to introduce a GST is not the answer. The government should be looking at ways to make work more attractive by reducing costs to employers at the same time as increasing disposable incomes. The GST is bad news for those who are trying to work. The government's proposed increases to pensions and benefits to compensate for the GST create new barriers to work. For example, a sole parent who does not work gets more per week out of the GST tax package than if he or she has a low paid job. A sole parent on maximum benefits gets an extra $26 a week out of the government's tax package. The sole parent earning $10,000 gets just $18.40. How can this be fair?

talk.start.para: âToday I want to make some commentsâand over the next few months I want to be able in various venues to make other commentsâabout the question of drugs and the problem particularly for our young people in Australia. I do not claim to have all the answers, but as a federal member, an Australian, a father and more recently a grandfather I am gravely concerned at the way in which the scourge of drug taking is having such a dramatic and tragic effect on so many people, especially our young people. It is time we reflected, took stock of what is happening and tried to draw some firm conclusionsâquite urgently, I thinkâabout what else can be done. Indeed, a lot has been done by a lot of good people and by governments on both sides of the political fence in Australia and other countries about this problem.

speech.para: The first point I would like to put right on the line is that I believe there is clear evidence that sections of the society that we belong to have developed a situation where they fail to take account of their responsibility to themselves. All human beings are expected to take responsibility for their own actions. There are good reasons why some people cannot do thisâpeople with profound intellectual disabilities, for example, require the help and protection of guardians, families and loved ones to help them through the difficult passages in their lives. But I want to make this point: many of the young people dying in the streets of capital cities in Australiaâin Melbourne in the last few weeks, about five a weekâdo not have a profound intellectual disability. They are perfectly normal and many of them have had many opportunities to make their way in life. Yet, unaccountably, they are doing this tragic thing to themselves. They are injecting with a dirty needleâor a clean needle, made available to them free, which has become dirty because of AIDS and other reasonsâa substance into themselves which they do not want to think about or know about but which will have a profound, devastating and probably addictive effect on them. The taking of responsibility has to be one of the core issues of the current debate. It is my view that, for some unaccountable reason, it has not been put forward strongly enough.

Many young people still join the scouting movement, thank goodness, but not as many as did in the past. Have you noticed that? Have you noticed the number of young people who do not get involved in community work, scouting or the service clubs? It may be due to many pressures, but they do not. One of the mottos in scouting was `Be prepared'. That had a many-faceted message in it. One was that you had to take account of the risks in life and you had to be prepared, fit and responsible. I put forward that there is overwhelming evidence that in this society there are some young peopleâfortunately not a majority but enough to worry youâwho are not for some reason taking responsibility for themselves. They have forgotten how to or never been taught how to. Whatever the reason, that is one of the things that I think we need to look at.

On the question of education, I am convinced that there needs to be a lot more done in respect of education. The Life Education project in Victoria involves a caravan which visits primary schools with skilled people demonstrating to young children what happens when you inject into the body, with graphic illustrations and models showing how the blood circulates through the organs with the drugs. I have heard it criticised by some people as being too simplistic. Yet I know, from talking with young people who have seen the Life Education project, how profoundly it affects them. Hopefully in later life, when they become more active and more free of parental control, they have the subconscious memory of how the organs in the body circulate substances injected into them, to the detriment of the body.

But I think there needs to be a lot more done. I know this might sound a little shocking but, having in my former legal practice appeared many times in coronial inquiries, I have a view that one of the things we might have to look at is that young people in secondary schools should be involved in what happens in the morgues in Australia. You cannot go to any city morgue in Australia during the week without seeing a young person lying dead on the slab from drug addiction, from an overdose, not being able to be revived by our fantastic emergency workers in the ambulance field. I wish to send a message of thanks to them for the harrowing work they are doing increasingly on a daily basis. But isn't it time that young people actually saw the devastation and the horror of what happens when the drugs go wrong all too frequently and it results in the loss of a young person?

What a frightening thing it isâI know these things are subject to coronial inquiries and there may be other facts that we do not knowâto read recent reports of young people going to clubs and parties and taking ecstasy and other tablets apparently as part of the buzz, the scene with the peer group pressure and all those sorts of things, and dying, as apparently has happened in the last 24 or 48 hours in Sydney. There was a comment by a bereaved parent who lost a daughter a couple of years ago in similar circumstances. What a horrific thing. Why is it that young people do that to themselves? Is it because they do not know what the effect is or they do not want to grapple with it, or is the answer halfway between the two? It is my view that there ought to be some more drastic and dramatic action taken along the lines of education, not only in the normal sense but also in the sense of having to confront the reality of what drugs do. Drugs kill young people. Drugs are killing young people every day, and I think it is important, to drive home the gravity of it, that young people actually see the dead bodies. I know that that sounds rather dramatic, but I put it with all sincerity.

On the question of rehabilitation, I think this is an area in which we obviously have a lot to learn. I am pleased to hear that naltrexone is now going to become available in Australia. Whilst I am not an expert on naltrexone, I understand that following general anaesthetic it has a dramatic effect on heroin addicts and, provided they are properly cared for, naltrexone will keep the heroin addict totally off heroin while they are under care with naltrexone. What happens after that, over a long period of time, we have to learn, but it seems to be a dramatic breakthrough.

I have actually had heroin addicts who have been through drug programs, referred through various programs that I have been indirectly involved in, beg me to oppose to my last breath making free heroin available on trials. They have explained to me that they have gone through the horror of addiction, crime, through the courts and finally to a rehab program as part of the condition to get their freedom. They have lost a family in the meantime and goodness knows what else. Having gone through the horrendous time of withdrawal, they have said to meâI do not know how many other members have experienced this; it would be interesting to hear their viewsâthat they believe that by making heroin free that would be tantamount to forcing them to go back in. That sounds rather strange intellectually, but I swear to you that is what has been put to me by a number of people who have been through the phase of drying out. The fear of going back on is very great. They fear that they will not be able to fight the urge to go back onto heroin if there is heroin available in some form of controlled way in society. Heroin is a horrific drug.

On the question of sanctions, I think that the gaols do not provide the complete answer, but society is saying to us that those people who traffic in drugs and who push drugs, especially to our young people, and destroy them, take their lives away, should be required to be subjected to mandatory gaol sentences. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âThis afternoon in the time allocated to me I want to talk briefly on the issue of East Timor. I first raised my own concerns about East Timor not long after I was first elected to this place in 1987. I have since that time been a consistent critic, first, of the Labor Party's position and the position of the then governments, both the Hawke and Keating governments, on this issue. My position has not changed. What I want to do is not to justify my own position but recall the fact that what we are about here in discussing East Timor in 1999 is the way ahead and not really looking at our own positions of the past. It seems to me that we are in a unique position historically to influence the course of events in what is our closest neighbour. Indeed, Darwin, the capital city of my electorate, is only 50 minutes from Dili by airâa lot closer than Jakarta.

speech.para: We need to comprehend that we have a historical association with both East and West Timor, an association which goes back many years but which was certainly at its peak in the Second World War, when we had Australian servicemen, soldiers of the 2/2nd and 2/4th commando units, in East Timor in 1942 and early 1943. The protection that was given to those people by the East Timorese community is a debt we have yet to repay, as many East Timorese died at the hands of the Japanese as a result of their collaboration with Australian forces. It is something which we as a nation are yet to deal properly with, and we now have the opportunity to do so.

We need to comprehend that opportunity in the light of current events in Indonesia and the advocacy by many people, not the least being the supporters of Xanana Gusmao, of the need for a process leading to independence for East Timor, a position which has been advocated successively by them for many years. Indeed, in 1991 I quoted Xanana Gusmao in an interview that he did with Robert Domm in late 1990 in which he said, `I am ready to discuss any project for a solution without preconditions and under the auspices of the United Nations.' It is that aspect of the current debate that I think we need to pay attention to.

Instead of being tardy about supporting an approach to the United Nations for them to participate actively in East Timor, we should be doing it. We should be promoting the idea that the United Nations, with our support and perhaps our direct involvement, should participate in East Timor; and we should do soâprovided, of course, we get the agreement not only of the Indonesians but also of the vari ous sections of the East Timorese community, who are currently in much public debate.

We need to recognise that, if we are to get a peaceful resolution to the ongoing difficulties of East Timor and if we are to provide the people of East Timor with the capacity to be self-determining, we have to give them every possible support. We need to understand that that will include a lot of assistance in terms of financial aid and developmental aid of different varieties. There is absolutely no doubt that the economy of East Timor is, in our terms, very poor. The standard of living of most East Timorese is very low. We know that people are in fact starving and that people have been denied access to the land as the result of military occupation, and that the land has been denuded.

We know that over recent times there has been very poor rainfall and that food crops have been poor. There has been a loss of huge swathes of forest cover, which has resulted in dry and very arid soils, and much of East Timor is barren land with only a thin veneer of soil over very stony subsoilâif subsoil is present at allâcovering much of the rolling hills to steeply sloping landscape that typifies the northern flank of the island. It is useful only for grazing, and only barely so. Under the Portuguese, their previous colonial masters, there were approximately 80,000 hectares of rice planted. My information is that now there are only between 20,000 and 30,000 hectares planted. Malnutrition, the prevalence of malaria and tuberculosis, as well as the flight and killings of pockets of local populations, have greatly reduced the family labour pool. There is a food shortage in East Timor and shortages of major resources, including essential infrastructure.

We know that, in terms of the East Timorese' aspirations for themselves, they have been denied access to an appropriate level and form of education. We know that only bahasa Indonesia is being taught in the schools and that Tetumâthe first language of most East Timoreseâis not taught. Indeed, they have been prevented from teaching it. We know that there are initiatives, most notably by the Mary MacKillop Institution in Sydney, which has been developing books in Tetum so that the East Timorese can learn their first language and become literate in it.

The opportunity that I spoke about earlier will require us not only to support any initiatives which involve the United Nations but also to understand our obligation to this community. We will have to provide the sorts of resources that will go to assist them in feeding and clothing themselves and providing essential community infrastructure, particularly in health, housing, education, roads and water. We have that obligation. It is something we should not shy away from, but something that we should accept as part of our neighbourly responsibilityâespecially as a result, as I said earlier, of our association in things past.

There is one initiative that Indonesia could take today which would have a marked bearing upon the eventual outcome of any discussions about the future of East Timor, and that is to release immediately Xanana Gusmao from his home detention and to allow him to anticipate actively in the developing debate about the future of East Timor, so that he can talk with people in East Timor and discuss with those people in East Timor who might be pro-integrationist and who oppose the possibility of self-determination, the chances of a reconciliation of the various groups of people who have different views.

We know that there are people in East Timor who have been armed by the Indonesians as militia and that these militia have been killing people. It is important that there be a process by which these people are disarmed and that indeed there be a cease-fire which involves all parties. Only then can we have a true dialogue, in my view, and only then will we get the outcome which will secure the future of the East Timorese community.

To do this, fundamentally there must be an appreciation of the crucial role of Xanana Gusmao, and I do not believe that people in Australia properly understand his importance. I know that he has had delegations meet him and most recently the Minister for Foreign Affairs of this nation. The US Secretary of State, Madeleine Albright, visited him last week. Gareth Evans has spoken to him, as has Laurie Brereton. Most people who are involved in this debate are speaking to Xanana Gusmao, yet he is under house arrest in Jakarta. He should be released to be able to be properly involved, both nationally and internationally, in discussions about the future of East Timor. He has very able lieutenants outside the country, not the least of whom is the Nobel laureate, Jose Ramos Horta. These people articulate very good positions, but there is absolutely no doubt in the world, in my view, that Xanana Gusmao is the leader of those people who are seeking an active role in getting active independence through a process of self-determination.

I say to those people in this country who are critical of our role in assisting this process: look at yourselves. We owe these people a great deal. They have every right to express their own futures in terms of an act of self-determination. We should not be walking away from them. We should be providing them with every possible support and this should include a commitment to financial and other aid, particularly in the period leading up to and including the period when they achieve some self-governance, and post that period, to ensure that that self-governance is sustainable. I implore the House to support the proposals for independence for East Timor and to support the East Timorese people.

talk.start.para: âIn her first speech to the House, the member for Lalor made the bold statement:

speech.para: One of the features of this parliament is that every few elections there arrives a new generation of politicians distinctly different from the people who preceded them.

The purpose of my remarks is to test the veracity of that statement, from a Labor member, and to consider whether it foreshadows a genuine change of culture taking place in the ALP, akin to that which took place in Britain after the election of Tony Blair as Labour's leader. The member for Hotham was once described to me by a New South Wales Labor operative as `an old-style trade unionist in a suit'. That was perhaps uncharitable. The member for Lalor is perhaps seeking to join the member for Werriwa, the member for Melbourne and, more recently, the member for Kingsford-Smith in her desire to put some ideological distance between herself and her party's leadership.

But the question is: do the maiden speeches of the member's colleagues bear out her assertion of a fresh, new direction for Labor? The first question is whether the ALP now represents something more than its traditional trade union constituency. It is hardly encouraging to find that the member herself boasts, as one of her qualifications for entering this place, that she spent eight years as an industrial lawyer defending trade unions.

Neither does the New South Wales election give much ground for optimism. It seems that you must be either a schoolmate of John Della Bosca a relative or spouse of John Della Bosca, or John Della Bosca himself, if you want to get Labor preselection.

The member for Griffith, in a letter to the Australian Financial Review on Thursday last week, was at pains to distance federal Labor from its trade union roots and to challenge unhelpful impressions created, not least by the Minister for Employment Services, who is at the table, in recent discussions about Labor's hereditary peers. The member for Griffith argued that no more than one-fifth of Labor's ranks in federal parliament were previously employed as party or union officials.

As a matter of public record, the Parliamentary Library Research Service records, in its list of previous occupations of members, 21 `party and union administrators' in Labor ranks. This is the figure, presumably, on which the letter is based. The member appears to have overlooked a second entry, further down the page, of `party and union officials'âa fine distinction indeedâcontaining an additional 11 members and senators, bringing the total to over one-third. If you study the Parliamentary Handbook, you find that, for occupations going back further than immediately prior to entering parliament, fully 44 of Labor's 95 members and senators are former union activists or actually on the payroll of organised labour.

I am not here to decry trade union membership. I am a former member of the trade union movement myself and still, somewhere, hold my BLF membership card, although I confess to now being unfinancial. Members on both sides of the House will appreciate the special contribution made by the BLF in New South Wales to fostering a modern industrial culture of cooperation and integrity. What I am addressing is the question of whether Labor is capable of getting out of the ACTU straitjacket and offering Australia a different vision, viewed through the maiden speeches of its new members.
The continuing intimacy of the nexus between the ALP and the ACTU was perhaps most neatly expressed by the member for Capricornia, who said:
From its inception, the Labor Party has been the political voice of the union movement.

The member conjures up an image of Labor's frontbench acting as a ventriloquist's dummy for the ACTU. We saw further evidence of this today, with the Teachers Federation apparently drafting most of Labor's questions in question time.

Turning from the member for Capricornia to the member for Charlton, a big chunk of her maiden speech was directed to thanking her comrades in the CFMEU, the AMWU and the maritime movement of Australia. She then moved to laud the ALP rank and file as:
. . . that great team of men and women who have affirmed their commitment to the policies . . . and traditions of the broader labour movement by becoming members of its political arm.

The member for Charlton is one of the more congenial, courteous and likeable members of the opposition, but I suspect she will not be accused of ushering in a new wave of creative Labor thought in this connection. In case we are under any illusion, we should understand from the ALP members and senators themselves that Labor is here to represent the ACTU.
On the question of giving the House an indication of the fresh policy perspective she would bring to the complex issues before us, she said:

Three of the issues . . . I will be opposing most vehemently in this House are those of the GST; the sale of Telstra; and the member for Flinders's capitalist agenda of attacking workers' rights and conditions, and further exploiting workers and their families to make way for increased profits for those whom the Liberal Party supportsâthe top end of town.

The member for Griffith, in spite of his lapse into factual sloppiness, is one of the more erudite and thoughtful members of the opposition. He is the sort of bloke upon which a party could build a new direction. There was some genuinely creative thought in his maiden speech but one simply notes that he has called for: increased expenditure on foreign aid, on multilateral agencies; increased expenditure on child care; radical increases in state and federal funding of secondary and tertiary education; increased expenditure on industry policy, including the rescue by government of insolvent companies; increased expenditure on public health; and increased expenditure on social welfare, especially in the number of public service administrators.

The member for Griffith rightly predicted that his remarks would be met by the inevitable chorus of `We cannot afford it', to which he responded, `I ask the question: as a nation, can we afford not to?' I suggest to the member for Griffith that, if future generations of Australians are labouring under a legacy of a massive debt, they will have a different view. One detects a note of irritation in many new Labor contributionsâirritation that responsible governments face spending constraints. For example, the member for Rankin was heard to say:
We should not be continually obliged to justify socially responsible policies in terms of the budget bottom line.
Reflect by contrast the stance of a truly modern Labour leader in Tony Blair's speech to the trade union movement in Bristol where he said:

Many people do not know that this year, as a result of the doubling of national debt, we will spend as much money paying back the interest on our debt as we spend on our schools, as we spend on law and order and as we spend on defence.
Members on this side of the House, perhaps naively, regarded good government as the art of the possible. Not according to the new member for Fowler who suggests:
It is simply not good enough for governments to limit their scope to what they see as possible.
I now turn to the member for Sydney who held out some signs of hope in her speech which contained an excellent quote from Edmund Burke. She said:
I am committed to a thinking party, a party of reform and progress. I was honoured to be part of the process of re-examining our national platform in the lead-up to the 1998 national conference.

This was the exercise presided over by the member for Holt after the 1996 landslide. It was the moment at which Australian Labor would decide whether it could break with the past, take on its own vested interests and offer a genuinely new vision to Australia. After all that work, consultation and discussion and the anticipation it created within Labor ranks and beyond, the member for Sydney was no doubt discouraged when the member for Holt finally announced:
Weâ
that is, the Labor Partyâ
would be utterly implausible if we tried to present ourselves to the electorate as a different outfit.
By contrast, Blair charts a new course. He said:
Our way is different. It is not a return to the past. There were good things that Labour governments achieved in the past but there were serious mistakes and we must not repeat them.
The member for Sydney gave voice to some lofty ideals in her first speech when she said:

We do a great disservice to the people we represent if we assume that they are looking for easy answers or glib pronouncements. We have to be prepared to argue through complex and subtle arguments. We must be prepared to rethink our own assumptions; to see merit in our opponents where it exists.

This is good stuff. This is the stuff from which a truly new Labor might be fashioned. What then do we find in the rest of the speech? How might it be judged in terms of questioning assumptions and seeing merit in opponents? The member for Sydney goes on to describe the government as `Hysterical with hatred; vicious; racist; appealing to and manipulating the worst in human nature' and finally describing one minister as `obscene'. And that was her first speech. Imagine what her grievance debates will be like. In her conclusion, she went on to give these tough policy pronouncements:
When in government again, we will build an environment in which the most vulnerable can provide for themselves and their families with dignityâbecause we are Labor.
Break out the violins. She continued:
We will create decent jobs with fair payâbecause we are Labor.
Serve up the apple pie. She continued:
And if they need a helping hand, we will be thereâbecause we are Labor.
The only thing she neglected to do was to tuck them in with a hot water bottle and a glass of warm milk. The challenge is before Labor. Let them rise to it. (Time expired)
