subdebateinfo.title: Second Sydney Airport: Environmental Impact Statement
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 211)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 26 November 1998:

question.para: (1) In March 1996, was the Government committed to an open, transparent and accountable environmental impact statement (EIS) process for Sydney's second airport; if so, is that still the case.

(2) Did the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation, as the Commonwealth's appointed environmental auditor, note in its review of the EIS that access to information about the Badgerys Creek assessment process was provided only at times and under conditions imposed by his Department and that access was denied to important information about the work of sub-consultants; if so, (a) was his Department acting independently or under ministerial direction, (b) why did the Department act in this way and (c) were the actions consistent with an open, transparent and accountable EIS process; if so, how.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) The Government is committed to conducting a thorough and transparent Environmental Impact Statement (EIS) process on the proposed second airport site at Badgerys Creek.

(2) SMEC Australia Pty Ltd (SMEC) was appointed to audit the EIS process on 14 November 1996 and it signed a contract for the audit with the Commonwealth on 6 March 1997. Before the contract was signed, full-time SMEC personnel were given access to EIS material. SMEC was asked, however, not to give access to its proposed sub-consultants without the approval of the then Department of Transport and Regional Development until a contract was signed and appropriate confidentiality agreements were in place.

These restrictions applied because of the sensitivity of some of the EIS material, the undefined scope of the audit and the absence of contracts between the Commonwealth and SMEC and between SMEC and its (proposed) sub-consultants. It is common practice for the Commonwealth to restrict access to sensitive information, particularly to organisations with which it does not have a contractual relationship.

The issue of access to EIS material was addressed through the development of a Confidentiality Agreement between the then Department of Transport and Regional Development and SMEC. This Agreement was signed on 27 February 1997 and was made publicly available.

The administration of the Confidentiality Agreement after 6 March 1997 was based on a list provided by SMEC of its sub-consultants and their specialist areas. The Department asked that access to documents be restricted to SMEC personnel and the relevant specialist sub-consultants.

In addition, the Department indicated that it would consider written requests for additional access by SMEC's sub-consultants. Several such requests were received and the Department agreed to them all. On one occasion the Department requested, mainly for practical reasons, that a sub-consultant review a large number of papers at the offices of the Department's EIS consultants.
SMEC was given access to the EIS consultant's technical files, with the exception of a small number of files which contained confidential management and commercial information.

Additional security measures were introduced in July 1997 when final drafts of the Draft EIS on Badgerys Creek and Holsworthy were available. The arrangements which applied to the audit team at that time were very similar to those which applied to the other agencies which were reviewing the documents at that time.

In summary, the Government did not restrict the Auditor's access to relevant EIS material and did not refuse any requests for access to material made after the Confidentiality Agreement with the Auditor was signed and the scope of the audit had been defined by Environment Australia. SMEC had access to all the technical information necessary for it to effectively review the data, methodologies and conclusions of the Draft EIS.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 26 November 1998:

question.para: (1) What requirements for dumping fuel are imposed on domestic and international air carriers and what is their legislative basis.
(2) Are penalties applied if the requirements are breached; if so, (a) what are they and (b) on how many occasions have they been applied since 1993.
(3) Is the Government able to eliminate the possibility of fuel dumping occurring over western and south-western areas of Sydney if an airport is constructed at Badgerys Creek.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) I am advised that the dumping of fuel from large aircraft is an unusual event which is allowed for in certain circumstances where an aircraft must reduce weight. An example of such a circumstance is an aircraft returning to an airport immediately after take-off following an engine failure or other safety related issue and fuel is required to be dumped so as not to exceed the maximum landing weight.

Civil Aviation Regulation 150âDropping of articles (CAR 150), as it applies to large jet aircraft, allows "in an emergency, the jettisoning of liquid fuel or cargo over areas where hazard to persons or property on the ground or water is not created".
The minimum height practice is designed to ensure that any jettisoned fuel will be vaporised completely.
(2) Yes.
(a) I am advised that the maximum penalty under CAR150 for the pilot in command of an aircraft involved in the illegal dropping of an object, including fuel, is $2750.00.
(b) The office of the Director of Public Prosecutions has advised my Department that no prosecutions have occurred under CAR 150 in relation to fuel dumping in the period since 1993.

(3) I am advised that, whenever possible, any aircraft using Sydney Kingsford Smith Airport that needed to dump fuel would be required to do so over the Tasman Sea at a minimum altitude of 6000 feet. This minimum height is designed to ensure that any jettisoned fuel will be vaporised completely. I am advised that a similar requirement would apply, whenever possible, for aircraft using the proposed Badgerys Creek Second Sydney Airport.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 26 November 1998:

question.para: (1) Has his attention been drawn to a newspaper article in the Sydney Morning Herald of 21 November 1998 in which the chief of Sydney (Kingsford Smith) Airport, Mr Tony Stuart, reportedly suggested that the airport has sufficient capacity to cater for future demand.
(2) Did the environmental impact statement for Sydney's second airport consider the logistical, economic, environmental and social consequences of not building a second airport; if not, why not.

(3) Did the Government base its assumptions on the future capacity of Sydney (Kingsford Smith) Airport on a study, assessment or report; if so, (a) what study, assessment or report, (b) when was it produced and (c) how confident is the Government in its findings.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Yes.

(2) The Draft Environmental Impact Statement (EIS) on the second airport proposal analysed the need for a second major airport for Sydney and considered the consequences of not building a second airport. Further work on these topics is being undertaken for the Final EIS.
(3) See answer to part (2) above.

subdebateinfo.title: Badgerys Creek Environmental Impact Statement: Model
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 235)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 30 November 1998:

question.para: (1) Has the NSW Environment Protection Agency developed a sophisticated model of the Sydney airshed; if so, was the model used in preparing the Badgerys Creek environmental impact statement (EIS); if not, why not.
(2) Were inadequate methodologies adopted as a basis for the air quality assessment in the EIS; if so, (a) why and (b) what action will he take to rectify the use of inadequate methodologies.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) As part of the air quality analysis for the Draft EIS on the Badgerys Creek airport proposal, it was planned to use the airshed model developed for the Metropolitan Air Quality Study undertaken by the NSW Environmental Protection Authority (NSW EPA). However, the NSW EPA did not provide access to the model and other valid, if less sophisticated, methods were used. The NSW submission on the Draft EIS indicates that the EPA's modelling produces estimates of ozone concentrations, should the airport proceed, similar to those presented in the Draft EIS.

(2) No. A number of air quality issues were raised in submissions on the Draft EIS and in the auditor's report. All submissions and the auditor's findings are being taken into account in the preparation of the Final EIS and further work is under way on some of the key issues, including air quality issues.

subdebateinfo.title: Badgerys Creek Environmental Impact Statement: Air Quality
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 236)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 30 November 1998:

question.para: (1) Did the assessment of air quality impacts in the Badgerys Creek environmental impact statement (EIS) allow for an estimated 70,000 motor vehicle movements per day associated with airport traffic; if not, why not.
(2) Did the EIS present a misleading understatement of the impact on air quality; if not, why not.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) and (2) Changes in urban development and the volume and distribution of motor vehicle traffic resulting from operation of the Second Sydney Airport would result in increases in air pollutant emissions over and above those generated by aircraft and other sources within the airport boundaries. In particular, increases in motor vehicle usage would occur along the main road links to the airport sites. The analysis in the Draft EIS indicates that motor vehicle emissions of nitrogen dioxide would be likely to amplify the increases in ozone levels predicted for the airport alone by 20 to 30 percent and that this could potentially expand the area affected by ozone impacts.

A number of air quality issues were raised in submissions on the Draft EIS and in the auditor's report. All submissions and the auditor's findings are being taken into account in the preparation of the Final EIS and further work is underway on some air quality issues.

subdebateinfo.title: Badgerys Creek Environmental Impact Statement: Greenhouse Gas Emissions
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 238)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 30 November 1998:

question.para: In view of Australia's agreement to restrict greenhouse emissions following the Kyoto conference, did the Badgerys Creek environmental impact statement consider the contribution of the airport and associated ground traffic to greenhouse gas emissions; if not, why not.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: The Draft Environmental Impact Statement on the proposal to develop a major airport at Badgerys Creek estimated that the annual greenhouse gas emissions from the airport alone in 2016 would be equivalent to 0.3 percent of the total NSW greenhouse gas emissions on the basis of current NSW projections extrapolated to 2016.

subdebateinfo.title: Badgerys Creek Environmental Impact Statement: Pollutants
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 239)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 30 November 1998:

question.para: (1) Do pollutants such as reactive organic chemicals and fine particles which are produced in motor vehicle and aircraft exhaust streams contribute to increases in the incidence of various cancers.
(2) Did the Badgerys Creek environmental impact statement ignore the impact on health of reactive organic chemicals and fine particles; if so, why.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) and (2) The Draft Environmental Impact Statement on the proposal to develop a major airport at Badgerys Creek assessed the health implications of increased exposure of the population surrounding the airport site to air toxins and particulates. Further work on this topic is being undertaken for the Final EIS.

subdebateinfo.title: Badgerys Creek Environmental Impact Statement: Aircraft Movements
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 271)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 2 December 1998:

question.para: Is it a fact that the Badgerys Creek environmental impact statement (EIS) is based on 360 000 aircraft movements per annum but that the risk analysis presented in the EIS is based on 245 000 movements per annum; if so, (a) is it standard practice for an EIS to use two separate figures for aircraft movement, (b) why is there a difference between the figures and (c) does the difference compromise the validity of the EIS; if not, why not.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (a),(b) and (c). The proposal put forward by the Government anticipated a major airport capable of handling 30 million passengers and up to about 360,000 aircraft movements per year. Air traffic forecasts developed for the Draft EIS showed that, on the assumption that a relatively high percentage of international flights would operate from the Second Sydney Airport, 30 million annual passengers could be accommodated by about 245,000 aircraft movements each year.

It was therefore appropriate for the Draft EIS to assess the airport operating at a level of 245,000 aircraft movements per year, rather than the 360,000 originally anticipated by the Government. The level of 245,000 annual aircraft movements has been used in the risk analysis as well as the assessment of the full range of other potential impacts.
Further environmental assessment may need to be undertaken in the future if it was found that the actual level of operations at the airport was likely to exceed 245,000 aircraft movements per year.

subdebateinfo.title: Badgerys Creek Environmental Impact Statement: Meteorological Data
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 272)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 2 December 1998:

question.para: (1) How important is meteorological data in the siting and operation of an airport.
(2) How many years meteorological data must be acquired before an accurate profile can be developed for the possible siting of an airport.
(3) How many years background meteorological data was available in preparing the Badgerys Creek environmental impact statement (EIS).
(4) Was sufficient meteorological data gathered for the Badgerys Creek EIS.
(5) How many years data was used in the Badgerys Creek EIS.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Meteorological data are required for airport design, for analysis of airport operations and for the assessment and management of environmental factors, including air quality and aircraft noise.

(2) and (3) The key issue is whether the data are sufficiently accurate to support the airport design and operational requirements. The time period for data collection depends on the meteorological parameter and its application.

(4) Several sources of meteorological data were available for the Draft EIS for the second airport proposal. All data sets were examined in detail and the most appropriate used in the analysis of the airport design and operations.

The availability of meteorological data was raised in a number of submissions on the Draft EIS. All submissions, and the auditor's findings, are being taken into account in the preparation of the Final EIS and further work is under way on some of the key issues, including meteorological issues.

(5) The collection periods for the meteorological data used in the Draft EIS varied from parameter to parameter. For example, the runway useability estimates were based on two years' data collected on the site. In contrast the estimates of the incidence of low cloud were based on records for Sydney and Bankstown airports extending over a 57 year period.

subdebateinfo.title: Badgerys Creek Environmental Impact Statement: Flora and Fauna Studies
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 276)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 2 December 1998:

question.para: (1) Upon what flora and fauna studies and surveys did the Badgerys Creek environmental impact statement (EIS) rely.
(2) On what dates were the studies and surveys originally published.
(3) Were new studies commissioned for the EIS; if not, why not.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) and (2) Full details of the scientific methods employed during data collection and the impact assessment work undertaken are contained in the Draft Environmental Impact Statement and in Technical Paper No.8.
(3) Yes.

subdebateinfo.title: Badgerys Creek Environmental Impact Statement: Meteorological and Air Quality Conditions
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 278)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 2 December 1998:

question.para: (1) Did his Department commission independent studies which concluded that vertical profiling of meteorological and air quality conditions was essential to achieve an accurate assessment of the impacts of the construction of Badgerys Creek airport; if so, (a) when were the studies undertaken and (b) were the results from the studies taken into consideration in the Badgerys Creek environmental impact statement (EIS); if not, why not.
(2) Was the EIS allowed to proceed without vertical profiling of meteorological and air quality conditions; if so, why.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Information on the vertical structure of winds and temperature in the lower atmosphere would improve the understanding of the meteorology at Badgerys Creek site and such data may be required for the operation of the airport. If available, such data could have been used for the Draft Environmental Impact Statement (EIS) to assist with detailed modelling of the air quality and noise impacts of the proposed airport.

(2) It was suggested in the Draft EIS that it would be prudent to undertake a sensitivity analysis of the results of the air quality study because of the lack of vertical profile data. This sensitivity study is being undertaken for the Final EIS.

subdebateinfo.title: Badgerys Creek Environmental Impact Statement: Compensation
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 279)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 2 December 1998:

question.para: Will the Commonwealth compensate the residents of western Sydney for loss of lifestyle, amenity and property value if the Badgerys Creek proposal proceeds; if so, how.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: These are matters for the Government to consider once a decision has been taken on the second Sydney airport.

subdebateinfo.title: Badgerys Creek Environmental Impact Statement: Archaeological Significance
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 280)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 2 December 1998:

question.para: (1) What studies were used in the Badgerys Creek environmental impact statement to determine the archaeological significance of the proposed site and when were they undertaken.
(2) How contemporary were the studies.
(3) How much of a site needs to be surveyed for an accurate assessment of Aboriginal heritage to be undertaken.
(4) Is he able to say whether a survey of 4 per cent of a proposed site meets internationally accepted standards.
(5) How much of the Badgerys Creek site was surveyed and are there proposals to survey more of the site.
(6) Did the survey include sub-surface indicators; if not, why not.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's questions is as follows:

answer.para: (1) and (2) A comprehensive literature search, oral research and field studies were undertaken in the context of the Draft Environmental Impact Statement. Reference was made to all recent archaeological work on the Cumberland Plain.
(3) There is no general answer to this question. The extent of survey coverage varies according to the research questions being addressed.
(4) I am advised that there are no internationally accepted standards in this area.
(5) The survey target of 33 per cent of the site area was exceeded for each of the three airport options. More of the site will be surveyed if the airport proposal proceeds.
(6) No. Sub-surface testing was not undertaken in order to minimise physical impacts and prevent unnecessary destruction of heritage sites.

subdebateinfo.title: Badgerys Creek Environmental Impact Statement: Aboriginal Culture
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 281)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 2 December 1998:

question.para: (1) Did the Badgerys Creek environmental impact statement (EIS) consider social, spiritual, cultural, health and psychological aspects of the Aboriginal environment; if not, why not.
(2) Is he able to say whether the factors referred to in part (1), in conjunction with archaeology, make up the Aboriginal cultural value of a location; if not, why not.
(3) Did the EIS consider the significance of Aboriginal bush foods, materials and medicines within the proposed airport site; if not, why not.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Social, health and psychological aspects of the communities living around the proposed airport site were considered in the Draft Environmental Impact Statement (EIS). Aboriginal spiritual and cultural aspects were also addressed in the context of the EIS.

(2) On the basis of consultations undertaken with aboriginal communities in the preparation of the Draft EIS, it was apparent that the factors referred to in (1) above are important components of Aboriginal culture.
(3) These issues were addressed in general terms in the Draft EIS. However, detailed analysis of the issues was considered to be outside the scope of the EIS.

subdebateinfo.title: Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport: Long Term Operating Plan
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 296)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 3 December 1998:

question.para: (1) Is the Long Term Operating Plan (LTOP) for Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport in operation; if not, why not.
(2) Is it a fact that the LTOP provides for 17 per cent of all flight departures to go north but in practice 34 per cent of all departures are to the north and over the electoral division of Lowe.

(3) Is it also a fact that (a) Air Services Australia have replaced an ethic based on noise amelioration with a profit-based ethic, (b) the $800 million road, rail, terminal and associated infrastructure-upgrades at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport are compromising the operation of the LTOP and (c) there is reluctance within Air Services Australia to implement the LTOP and noise sharing arrangement.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Yes.

(2) No. The LTOP target is for all movements to the north of the Airport to account for about 17% of all operations at the Airport. Of these 17%, seven percentage points are departures to the north off the main north-south runway and 10 percentage points are arrivals from the north onto the parallel runways. Radar track runway use data indicates that since December 1997 departures to the north off the main north-south runway which overflew the electoral division of Lowe made up about 5% of all movements at the Airport.

(3) No. Airservices Australia is bound by Government direction to implement the Long Term Operating Plan subject to the limits set by safety considerations and the operational constraints which may vary from day to day.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 3 December 1998:

question.para: Will the proposed second Sydney airport solve the aircraft noise impact on Sydney residents and the motor traffic servicing Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport; if so, how.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: The Government remains committed to ensuring the effective management of aircraft noise impacts on Sydney residents arising from the operations of Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport. As part of this commitment it has moved to cap the hourly aircraft movement rate at the airport at 80, and has implemented the Long Term Operating Plan that has been very effective in moving towards a more equitable basis for sharing aircraft noise.

To supplement these actions, the Government has proposed the development of a second airport at Badgerys Creek to meet future aviation demand in the Sydney Basin. The construction of a second airport will assist in the management of aircraft noise impacts on Sydney residents by providing an alternative to Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport for aviation traffic.

talk.start.para: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 10 December 1998:

question.para: (1) Is he responsible for approving the granting of financial assistance in respect of proceedings under the Workplace Relations Act 1996 .

(2) Since 2 March 1996, has he approved financial assistance to a person, association, organisation or corporation in respect of proceedings under the Workplace Relations Act 1996 ; if so, (a) how many grants have been approved and (b) in each case, (i) what sections of the Act relate to the proceedings for which the assistance was approved, (ii) what sum was or will be paid and (iii) was an industrial organisation of employees a party to the proceedings if so; which organisation.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Under section 342 of the Workplace Relations Act 1996 I may authorise the payment of financial assistance in relation to a person's relevant costs in respect of the various proceedings and inquiries referred to in subsection 342(2). I do not personally approve grants of financial assistance as I have delegated the decision making to officers within my Department.

(2) Subsection 342(2) of the Workplace Relations Act 1996 restricts the granting of financial assistance to individuals and specifically excludes organisations from being granted any financial assistance.
I am advised that
(a) From 2 March 1996 to 18 January 1999, 12 applications for financial assistance were approved under section 342 of the Workplace Relations Act 1996.
(b) (i) Two (2) applications concerned section 208, eight (8) applications concerned section 209, one (1) application concerned section 218 and one (1) application concerned section 219.

(ii) Payments made in respect of grants of financial assistance made under section 342 of the Workplace Relations Act 1996 since 2 March 1996 amount to $79,659.57 while outstanding commitments amount to $85,634.28.

(iii) There exists a long standing practice, endorsed by successive Attorneys-General, to treat applications for Commonwealth financial assistance in confidence. This practice extends to neither confirming nor denying that particular applications have been received and accords with the requirements of the Privacy Act 1988. Consequently it would not be appropriate to provide details in relation to any individual applications for assistance.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Special Minister of State, upon notice, on 8 February 1999:

question.para: (1) Did the Australian Electoral Commission (AEC) relocate its divisional office for Grayndler from Ashfield to Haymarket; if so, (a) why and (b) will the divisional office for Grayndler be re-established within Grayndler's electoral boundaries; if so, when; if not, will the divisional office for Grayndler remain at Roden Cutler House in Haymarket.
(2) Will the AEC relocate the divisional office for Lowe to Roden Cutler House in Haymarket.

talk.start.para: âThe Special Minister of State has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: As honourable members are aware, the Australian Electoral Commission (AEC) is an independent statutory authority. Under the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918, a divisional office can be located outside the boundaries of the electorate with the permission of the Electoral Commission. The Special Minister of State has therefore sought the AEC's advice on the history of the Divisional Office for Grayndler.

The AEC has advised that the Divisional Office for Grayndler was relocated from Ashfield to the AEC's Sydney Head Office site at Roden Cutler House, 24 Campbell Street Sydney, in 1997, following a fire safety report which recommended urgent relocation.

The accommodation in Ashfield had been recognised as unsuitable for some time and the AEC had been actively seeking alternative accommodation within the Grayndler divisional boundaries, without success.

The Australian Electoral Officer for New South Wales wrote to the honourable Member for Grayndler on 29 July 1996 to confirm that the AEC needed to move from its premises in Ashfield because the building was subject to an unsatisfactory safety report. This letter also confirmed discussions between the Divisional Returning Officer for Grayndler and Mr Tim Gartell, of Mr Albanese's electoral staff, that the Member did not oppose any proposal to relocate the Office outside the Divisional boundaries.

On 10 March 1997, following an electrical fault in the Divisional Office for Grayndler's premises at Ashfield, the Australian Electoral Officer for New South Wales again wrote to the honourable member advising him of her intention to immediately seek the Electoral Commission's approval to relocate the Office, temporarily to a small area on Level 6 of Roden Cutler House. The Electoral Commission gave approval for the relocation of the Divisional Office for Grayndler outside the electoral boundaries on 13 March 1997. Electors in the Division were notified of the relocation through advertisements in the local press.
In 1998, the AEC entered into a new lease at Roden Cutler House, which enables the Divisional Office for Grayndler to be collocated with the Divisional Office for Sydney in larger premises.

The Division of Grayndler covers 28.9 sq km of inner metropolitan Sydney. It is immediately adjacent to the Division of Sydney, where the Divisional Office is now located. The availability of both rail and bus makes the Divisional Office in its current location more conveniently accessible to electors from other parts of the Division than was previously the case when it was located in Ashfield. Disabled parking is available immediately outside the building, as is metered parking. There are also several public car parks in the immediate vicinity. Arrangements can also be made for parking in the building itself.

Pre-poll, postal and ordinary voting services were available for Grayndler electors at the 1998 Election, as usual. A pre-poll centre was located in the Division at 297B Victoria Road Marrickville, which was open from 21-25 September and from 28 September until polling day. Electors were also able to cast a pre-poll vote at any other pre-poll centre across the country. On 3 October, polling centres were open across the Division from 8.00am until 6.00pm, as usual.

In relation to the location of the Divisional Office for Lowe, the AEC has advised that on 10 July 1998, the Australian Electoral Officer for New South Wales wrote to the former Member for Lowe seeking his views on a collocation of the Divisional Office for Lowe with the Divisional Offices for Sydney and Grayndler in Roden Cutler House. The Australian Electoral Officer for New South Wales has already advised the new Member for Lowe that she will formally seek his comments should further consideration be given to relocating the Divisional Office for Lowe.
